text:
Welcome to How To Cook That I am Ann Reardon
Today we are making a lego batman cake. I

have had so many requests for lego movie cakes,
lego cakes and a batman cakes so here it is
a fun cake for you.

Firstly cut out the template, join any of
the big pieces that have a joining lines together

with some tape and then make sure that the
whole cake is going to fit on your cake board

because this is quite a tall and quite a wide
cake once you put those arms on.

Smear a small amount on frosting onto the
board and then add your first tray cake. Cover

that in frosting and then add two more layers
of cake. I am using two trays of chocolate

cake and one white chocolate cake in the middle
and that is so that is makes it easier for

me to show you how to carve the cake later
on.

Using the template check that your cake is
the correct height for the body of batman.

We will use off cuts to build up the head
height later so we are just looking at the
body height at the moment.

Place the template over the top of your cake
and cut around it using a serrated knife using

an up and down motion.
The cutting template and the video recipes

for the cakes and the frosting are all detailed
on the website howtocookthat.net, I'll put

a link to the recipe in the description just
below this video for you.

Once you've cut the whole shape out we need
to build up the head section. Using one of

the off cuts take one layer off the top and
add it to the head section of the cake.

Then use your template again to trim it to
the right shape.

Now to carve the cake to give it lego figure
shape. Take the cake cutting templates for

the feet, legs and body and place them all
over to line up with the left hand side of

the cake.
Then add the face and place it over on the
right hand side of the head.

Now using the template as a guide cut off
any extra cake that is on the taller layer

that you added where batmans head finishes.
So we've got a nice straight line at the bottom
of his head.

Now I want to build up the right hand side
of his chest. So just like you did for the

head take a layer from some of the off cut
cake and add it to the top right of the chest.

Use your knife to slice it down on an angle
so it comes down on a nice smooth curve like
a smooth skate ramp.

Place the body template back on top lining
it up with the left edge again and then trim

the cake from along the top edge of the paper,
down to the base of the cake where you cut

before using the bigger template so you end
up with an edge that angles outward.

Do the same with his right foot, there is
not much that you need to trim there just
a little bit.

And then the left foot, remembering you are
not cutting this straight down you are cutting
on an angle out to the base.

Add the body template and indent straight
lines across the base and then across the

top and bottom of the leg pieces so now they
will guide your next cuts.

For the leg section we want to almost take
off a whole layer, but we want it to have
like a speed bump in the middle.

For the hip area, cut a straight line down,
and then cut a flat layer about 2/3 of the

way through that top layer of cake and take
that peice off.

Again on the other leg cut out a speed bump.
Lego figures have that central join part between

the legs, cut down the side of that and then
round that around down the front. Then trim

off about 1/3 of the top layer so it is taller
than the hip section but shorter than the

body.
Then for the hip area just like we did on

the other cut off a flat layer about 2/3 of
the way through the top layer of cake.

Now to carve the head, place the template
over the top and round off the corners on

the side of the head and the cheek, Now we
don't want to make this straight we want to

make it rounded like a lego head. Then round
off towards the ears. It helps here if you

have either a print out picture like I do
to look at or a lego figure if you've got
one would be even better.

Lots of people ask does anyone actually make
these cake, and the answer is yes, if you

head on over to the website and look at the
comments section you can see some amazing

pictures of the cakes people make using these
videos. Often they have never worked with

fondant before or are only 14 or 15 years
old sometimes. That is the beauty of these

videos you can pause them and go through step
by step.

Trim off a triangle of cake where the body
meets the head. For most of the cake we will

leave it flat at the base but for the head
we want to round it around to the cake board.

So now your cake is carved and is starting
to look like a lego figure. Cover the whole

cake in frosting. I am using a mixture of
buttercream and ganache here which is my favourite

frosting to use for carved cakes. Once you've
covered the whole cake place it in the fridge

to firm up a bit for at least 10 minutes.
You can leave it for longer but just give

it at least 10 minutes.
Now for his clothes, I suggest you buy pre-coloured

black fondant for this or you'll likely end
up with light grey and batman only wears black
and sometimes very very dark grey.

Roll it out on some non-stick baking paper.
Then using the paper lift the fondant up and

flip it over your cake. and then peel off
the paper.

Lift and smooth the sides of the fondant at
the edges

Gently push it down to mold it around the
shape of your batman and then use your thumb

and finger just like I am here to pinch and
make a sharp edges around the body and the

top and sides of each foot. SO you get like
a nice crisp straight line along there.

Just take your time doing this, if you could
be any superhero which one would you be, I

don't know if any of them have skills that
would help in cake decorating, but being able

to fly would be fun, lots of them can fly
so what other super hero skills would you

like to have?
Use a ruler as you go around the foot as well

to make sure the sides of the foot are nice
and straight just like they are on the lego.

Now cut off the extra fondant, I always cut
this bigger than I think i need and then tuck

it in, you can always cut more off but if
you make it too short you're a bit stuck.

Continue defining the fondant, use a smooth
ruler thats not sharp to push it in around

that neck. Even though it is one big piece
of fondant we want it to look like it is different

sections just like a piece of lego has the
different sections for the head and the body

and the legs. Using your ruler make another
indent across the body, there is a guideline
for that on the template if you need it.

For between the legs, when you trim the fondant
there will not be enough to cover down between

the legs. Roll out a rectangle of fondant
and put it into place and press that on.

Now for his face.
Roll out some lego batman skin colour and

use the template to indent where the mouth
section, cut out not on the indent but slightly

bigger than that.
Then on the edges use your finger to smooth

down the fondant so that you can't see a hard
edge.

Roll out some black and use the template to
cut out the face, then indent where the eyes

and mouth are and cut them out too. Roll out
some white and add it above the mouth colour

and smooth the edges down. Now take the black
and place it over the top. Put your template

back over and use that to arrange the black
in just the right position because it probably

will have moved when you were transferrin
it over.

Peel it off and place it onto your cake over
the the right hand side of the head. Using

the nose template to guide the size form a
pyramid on its side for the nose and put that
into place.

Cut out the white teeth and place that fondant
on top, you can use a tiny bit of water under

the fondant to make it stick.
Now for the body muscle lines, place the template

over and indent using the back of your knife
where all those muscle lines go.

Take some silver luster dust and mix it with
either lemon juice or alcohol and paint it

on over the indents that you just made. Have
a batman picture in front of you so you know

what it is supposed to look like as you paint.
That just makes it heaps easier. Now for his

cape. Take the cape template and cut out some
black fondant and place it against the side

of your cake. We don't want the cape completely
flat so put some non-stick baking paper underneath

it and lift it up using some scrunched up
foil to shape it how you want it. So that

it looks like the cake is flapping in the
wind.

For some fondant details you need the fondant
to set hard so it holds its shape. You can

do that by either making them ahead and letting
them dry and you can make them up to 3 weeks

ahead and just store them in open air not
in a sealed container and they will dry out.

Or you can add tylose powder to the fondant.
You need about 1/2 a teaspoon of tylose to

250g of fondant. Just put the powder on the
counter and knead it into the fondant. This

makes the fondant dry out quicker so you'll
need to work with it fairly quickly with it

and store any left over bits you're not working
with in a ziplock bag so it doesn't dry out.

Now to make the batarang. Roll and cut out
the basic shape, then add a strip to each

side along the top. Cut two more strips and
place them going down as you can see on the
template.

For the handle part where he holds onto it
you need to roll a cylinder and cut it in

two. Place one half of it onto the middle
section of the batarang and just leave the
other one for the moment.

To make the hands find something that is about
the size of the circle shown on the template

take some non-stick baking paper around it.
Cut out the hand shape and wrap it around

your cylinder.
One we can leave on the cylinder to harden,

the other one we want on the batarang handle.
because once that fondant it hard if you try

and open up to clip it onto the batarang it's
just going to break. . To do that we need

to support the sides of the batarang I am
using cardboard covered in non-stick baking

paper and propping it up using foil underneath
it. Put the other half of the cylinder underneath

and then wrap the hand around it. Then put
the whole thing into place on your cake board

so that it can dry there.
Now for the arms, take a chocolate bar that

is bendy, usually the ones with firm caramel
in them are fairly moldable. Squash it an

mold it to the shape of the arms.
For the longer arm take a lollipop stick and

push that into the centre of the chocolate
bar. Wrap it up using fondant making sure

the join it at the back and not the front
of the arm.

Fold in the ends and push it into the cake
so it is coming out on and upwards angle.

We don't want it flat we want it like he is
pointing up. Roll a little cylinder for the

wrist and then using a small amount of water
on it and add the hand. While that joint is

drying and firming into place you are going
to need to add a cup place it underneath the

support it while the joint dries.
Repeat that for the other arm, except that

this one does not need a lollipop stick as
it is will be sitting flat on the cake board.

Now for our belt, cut out the yellow pieces
using the template and then stick them into

place across the cake, using your knife to
push the edges to straighten them up.

To make the batman logo cut around the oval
shape and again use the edge of a knife to

smooth it off.
Roll out some black and cut out the bat symbol.

Use a straw to cut out and smooth off those
inner rounded edges.

Lift it up and place it on your yellow oval.
Put a little water on the chest and add it
into place.

Using a paint brush and some black gel food
colouring paint the belt lines across the

top. You can see where these lines need to
go from the template and you can indent them

on if needed or just do it free hand.
The mouth also needs outlining with the black

then draw in the little line on one side.
Lego figures are shiny so I am going to spray

this cake with an edible shiny laquer for
cakes. I did a test last night so I could

show you, this is one is the black sprayed
with the laquer black and it is nice and shiny,

but on the painted piece the black gel colour
has run a a little bit on it. So to make sure

that doesn't happen on our finished cake I
am putting a piece of baking paper over our

painted sections so that they don't run or
smudge at all. Give it a good spray all over.

Once the details are dry you can remove the
supports and the batarang is big enough and

heavy enough that it will still need some
support for it's weight so add a small black

circle of fondant underneath each end.
And there you have it an awesome lego batman
cake that would be the highlight of any party.
Click on the links below to share the video.

Subscribe to how to cook that for more creative
cakes, desserts and chocolate.

Last weeks video was how to make peanut butter
chocolate brownies, this button will take

you to the channel where you can see all of
the videos and this one gets you to the recipe
website.

If you're on a mobile or tablet then all of
those links are in the description as well
for you.
Have an awesome week and I'll see you Friday.
